title: Thursday Morning Business Brief
text:
October 22, 2015, 6:27 AM SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA - 
European stocks were flat ahead of today's European Central Bank policy meeting, and Asian markets outside China were mostly lower after disappointing U.S. earnings reports dented investor sentiment. U.S. stocks finished in the red yesterday with Yahoo slumping more than 5 percent. WASHINGTON (AP) - The Labor Department releases weekly jobless claims today. Freddie Mac releases weekly mortgage rates. The National Association of Realtors will report on existing home sales for September. Southwest Airlines, Caterpillar, 3M, United Continental, McDonald's and Union Pacific will report their quarterly earnings before the market opens. Alphabet Inc., Amazon.com and Microsoft will report after. WASHINGTON (AP) - Washington is barreling toward a Nov. 3 deadline to raise the government's borrowing cap and avert a first-ever default on U.S. payments, but there's no sign yet on Capitol Hill of a viable solution. Instead, the Republican-controlled House is moving ahead on tea party-blessed legislation that has no chance of making it through the Senate, much less of being signed by President Barack Obama. Credit markets are already nervous about the lack of progress. DETROIT (AP) - The United Auto Workers union was expected today to release results of a vote on a tentative contract deal reached with Fiat-Chrysler. If approved, the union will use the Fiat Chrysler deal as a template for talks with Ford and General Motors. LUXEMBOURG (AP) - The European Union's top court says the Bitcoin virtual currency that is used online and over the Internet should be exempt from sales taxes within the 28-country bloc. The European Court of Justice says today that there was no reason to treat Bitcoin differently than other transactions involving "currency, bank notes and coins used as legal tender."
